Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 43436-01 
Regional–Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
February 2010 
 
 
 
 
Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CDDE  –  Capacity Development for Development Effectiveness 
DMC  –  developing member country 
HLE  –  high-level event 
HLF-4  –  Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness 
MfDR  –  managing for development results 
  OECD-DAC  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-
    Development Assistance Committee  
SPD  –  Strategy and Policy Department 
SSC  –  south-south cooperation 
UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme 
WP-EFF  –  Working Party on Aid Effectiveness 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management, public expenditure and fiscal management, public 
administration) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development; client relations, 
    network, and partnership development); regional cooperation and 
    integration (other regional public goods); governance 
Location Impact  –  Regional (high), national (high) 
Partnerships  –  Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, United 
Nations Development Programme, World Bank, Government of 
Japan 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
Director General  K. Sakai, Strategy and Policy Department (SPD) 
Director   I. Bhushan, Strategic Planning, Policy and Interagency Relations Division, SPD
   
Team leader  M. Senapaty, Principal Planning and Policy Specialist, SPD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This  regional  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  allow  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and its developing member countries (DMCs) to effectively participate 
at the Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness (HLF-4) to be held in the Republic of 
Korea in 2011 and in preparatory activities leading to the event.1 The TA also represents ADB’s 
ongoing commitment to the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness (the Paris Declaration), as 
expressed by the President at the Second High-Level Forum (HLF-2) in Paris in March 2005 
and subsequently reaffirmed at the Third High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness (HLF-3) in 
Accra, Ghana in September 2008. The concept note on this subject was approved on 28 
September 2009. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Commitment to support global efforts to enhance aid effectiveness. ADB, as a part 
of the development community, participated in the HLF-1 held in Rome in 2003, which identified 
a general framework for harmonization and alignment; the HLF-2, which produced the Paris 
Declaration; and the HLF-3, which endorsed the Accra Agenda for Action. ADB organized and 
participated  in  a  number  of  key  events  notably  the  regional  consultation  workshops  in 
preparation for the HLF-2 and HLF-3, the post-Paris consultations and monitoring surveys, and 
the managing for development results (MfDR) round tables and related activities. As a follow-up 
to the HLF-3, ADB facilitated DMC capacity development through peer-to-peer learning as part 
of the Capacity Development for Development Effectiveness (CDDE) Facility program.2  
 
3.  Focus on improving aid effectiveness in the region. ADB is currently finalizing the 
results of its third aid effectiveness survey covering aid disbursed to 25 countries in the Asia 
and Pacific region in 2008. While ADB has made significant progress in meeting its Paris 
Declaration commitments and in the three Accra Agenda for Action focus areas, much more is 
required  to  improve  aid  effectiveness  and  development  effectiveness  in  the  region.  This 
requires international, ADB-wide, and country actions. It will also require continued efforts in 
pursuing current initiatives including enhancing capacity development; strengthening country 
ownership; mainstreaming the principles of aid effectiveness in ADB policies, strategies, and 
operating guidelines; and building more effective and inclusive international partnerships to 
influence global policy and actions on key issues. 
 
4.  Greater role for ADB in HLF-4. ADB played a key role in the HLF-3. Since the HLF-4 is 
to be held in Asia and the Pacific and be hosted by an important partner—the Republic of 
Korea—ADB is expected to play an even more active role in organizing and supporting the 
event as well as the preparatory activities. The Working Party on Aid Effectiveness (WP-EFF) of 
the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and 
Development (OECD-DAC) is beginning to prepare for the HLF-4. The HLF-4 and the analysis 
that  feeds  into  it  will  assess  how  countries  and  development  partners  have  performed  in 
delivering  on  their  commitments.  The  concept  note  and  draft  agenda  are  currently  being 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 23 October 2009. 
2  To support DMC capacity development needs for in-country implementation of the Paris Declaration, a joint 
development partner initiative—the CDDE Facility—was launched in Manila in March 2009 with support from the 
Government of Japan, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Regional Center Bangkok, and World 
Bank. ADB 2009. Technical Assistance for the Governance and Capacity Development Initiative (Phase 2). Manila 
(TA 7277-REG) provided $150,000 to the joint development partners' fund managed by UNDP, Regional Center 
Bangkok.  http://www.adb.org/Aid-Effectiveness/default.asp  and  http://www.aideffectiveness.org/CDDE-Capacity-
Development-for-Development-Effectiveness-Facility.html

2     
 
finalized  by  the  HLF-4  organizing  committee  in  consultation  with  development  partners.  A 
discussion of the preparatory works follows. 
 
5.  Promote  south-south  cooperation  to  enhance  cooperation  effectiveness  and 
achieve development results. As a member of the task team on south-south cooperation 
(SSC), ADB is expected to play a significant role in the High-Level Event (HLE) on South-South 
Cooperation  and  Capacity  Development  to  be  held  in  March  2010  in  Colombia.  After 
documenting and analyzing SSC experiences and their synergies with the aid effectiveness 
agenda, the task team intends to identify and agree on good SSC practices. This analytical work 
will be disseminated and discussed at the HLE in the context of aid effectiveness. 
 
6.  As a member of the steering committee, ADB is expected to, among others, (i) support, 
follow up, and supervise thematic preparation for the HLE on SSC, particularly regarding the 
work of round tables and corresponding analytical work; (ii) promote and ensure synergies and 
balances  between  the  SSC  and  capacity  development  agendas,  (iii)  prepare,  share,  and 
consolidate the ministerial and heads of delegation recommendations for the HLE regarding 
SSC and capacity development; and (iv) safeguard the integration of the HLE in the broader 
logic of the process leading from Accra 2008 via the HLE in 2010 and HLF-4 in 2011. ADB will 
also facilitate participation of some DMCs in the Asia regional meeting. 
 
7.  Strengthen capacity development of DMCs. ADB will help strengthen the voice of 
partner countries through the south–south initiatives financed by the CDDE Facility. The facility 
made significant progress in building DMC capacity, and facilitating implementation of the Paris 
Declaration in the region.3 The continued support to the CDDE Facility through this TA is 
necessary  to  provide  assistance  to  the  DMCs  on  issues  related  to  aid  effectiveness,  and 
strengthen input from Asia and the Pacific for the HLF-4. The CDDE work plan for 2010 and 
2011 is being prepared using consultations with the Asia-Pacific community of practice on aid 
effectiveness, set up by the CDDE Facility. All facility south-south initiatives have capacity 
development at their core and a concern with monitoring country results. 
 
8.  Improve the use of conditionality that reinforces country ownership. ADB co-chairs 
a task team on conditionality under the transparent and responsible aid cluster of the WP-EFF. 
ADB will undertake joint analytical work, participate in country consultations, and disseminate 
good practices on conditionality with other members of the task team. The outcomes of this 
work will also feed into the HLF-4.  
 
9.  Support DMC participation at the HLF-4. ADB will support DMC participation in the 
HLF-4 as well as in the preparatory meetings. Through subregional consultations, ADB will draw 
on the views of its partner countries and civil society organizations to assess the impact of the 
Paris  Declaration  on  Aid  Effectiveness  across  the  region,  and  facilitate  development  of 
perspectives and priorities on aid effectiveness for Asia and the Pacific. 
 
10.  This TA is therefore required to ensure effective participation of the DMCs and ADB in 
the HLF-4 and in the preparatory activities; and through such participation to enhance country 
ownership and leadership, and influence global policy on aid effectiveness.  
 
 
 
                                                 
3  Details are provided in the Six-Month Progress Report of the CDDE Facility at www.aideffectiveness.org.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA will contribute to global efforts to improve international aid effectiveness policies 
and development partner approaches that are aligned to DMC needs in the region. The TA's 
outcome will be enhanced country ownership and leadership of the aid effectiveness agenda. 
 
12.  The  expected  outputs  are  (i)  best  practices  and  country-specific  examples  to  be 
presented at the HLE on SSC and the HLF-4; (ii) a regional perspective document and regional 
consultation reports on key HLF-4 themes; (iii) report on shared experiences and common 
issues with MfDR to be presented at the HLF-4; (iv) CDDE Facility outputs, such as initiatives 
reports and annual progress reports based on the work plan for 2010 and 2011; and (v) 
documented best practices of development partners on conditionality. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  Activities for the 2010 HLE on SSC and capacity development and the 2011 HLF-4 
include 
 
(i)  support for the participation of DMCs in (a) the January 2010 regional meeting in 
Asia, including financing of travel and accommodation costs, and preparation of 
case studies; (b) the OECD-DAC 2010 survey (organization of regional workshop 
and country support through resident missions); and (c) the 2011 HLF-4 (both 
from government and civil society organizations) including financing of travel and 
accommodation costs, and preparation and participation at the marketplace);  
 
(ii)  organization of the consultation process within Asia and the Pacific in 2010 and 
2011 (holding of several subregional workshops and publication of reports); 
 
(iii)  ADB's  own  contribution  and  participation  at  the  HLE  and  HLF-4  (including 
preparation  of  case  studies,  staff  contribution  for  round  tables  and  plenary 
sessions,  organization  of  side  events,  participation  at  the  marketplace, 
preparation of ADB survey reports);  
 
(iv)  dissemination  of  packages  and  reports  to  improve  awareness  of  the  HLF-4 
process within and outside of ADB; and 
 
(v)  financing of DMC-led follow-up subregional and country activities (2010–2011). 
14.  ADB is part of the CDDE Facility secretariat and the steering committee, and will be 
closely involved in preparing the CDDE work plan for 2010 and 2011. The United Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP) Regional Center Bangkok will administer the CDDE activities 
and manage resources based on the agreed work plan.  
 
15.  ADB, as a co-chair of the task team on conditionality, will contribute documentation of 
good practice, and country dissemination of such practices. The outcomes of this work will feed 
into the HLF-4.

4     
 
16.  ADB will organize a regional meeting of the community of practice of MfDR members at 
a location and date to be determined to share experiences and ideas about the use of MfDR for 
achieving development outcomes, and identify common issues to be presented at the HLF-4. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The  TA  is estimated  to  cost  $700,000,  to  be  financed on  a  grant  basis  by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). This amount includes (i) consulting services; and 
(ii)  training,  seminars,  and  conferences  (for  the  consultation  meetings  including  travel  of 
resource persons and DMC participants). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  A steering group will be set up to provide guidance on major decisions on various 
aspects of HLF-4 activities, agree on ADB's position from an institutional perspective, and 
systematically facilitate early decisions on major activities. The steering group will be headed by 
the director general of ADB’s Strategy and Policy Department (SPD) and comprise senior staff 
(depending on the specific agenda of the HLE and HLF-4, which is being prepared by the WP-
EFF, of which ADB is a member). An interdepartment working group will be set up to coordinate 
elements of aid effectiveness covering issues of public financial management, procurement, and 
results; and to develop a coordinated work plan to prepare for the HLF-4 and preparatory 
activities. The working group will be led by the Strategy, Planning, Policy and Interagency 
Relations Division.   
 
19.  SPD will implement the TA from December 2009 to May 2012. ADB will be the executing 
agency. SPD, specifically the Strategy, Planning, Policy and Interagency Relations Division, will 
administer the TA in cooperation with the regional departments, resident missions, and other 
staff depending on the topics for the 2010 HLE and 2011 HLF. CDDE activities will be managed 
and implemented by the UNDP Regional Center in Bangkok. Through this TA, ADB will provide 
$150,000 to the joint development partners' fund that UNDP will manage. For this purpose, an 
administrative  arrangement  between  ADB  and  UNDP  will  be  signed  as  set  out  in  the 
memorandum of understanding between them dated 23 July 2007. Consultants will be engaged 
to provide technical support and administrative and logistical assistance (for organization of 
workshops,  seminars,  and  other  activities).  Estimated  inputs  of  7  person-months  from 
international consultants and 12 person-months from national consultants will be required. The 
outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will engage the consultants on 
an individual basis and in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). A no-objection letter will be obtained from each DMC where DMC-
specific activities will be conducted. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance 
with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4  
 
20.  SPD will work with the regional departments to organize the workshops and prepare the 
necessary materials for the consultations.  
 
21.  To  ensure  timely  and  effective  dissemination  of  results  and  deliverables  from  the 
consultation  workshops,  plans  are  in  place  to  ensure  that  the  consolidated  report  and 
summaries  of  discussions  at  the  workshops  will  be  disseminated  to  the  DMCs  and  other 
development institutions. These reports will also be distributed at the HLF-4. 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

5
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for 
the Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Aid Effectiveness/Development Effectiveness Experts on Topics of Fourth High-
Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness (international consultants, 5.5 person-months) 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will support Asian Development Bank (ADB) participation 
in the High-Level Event (HLE) on South–South Cooperation and Capacity Development and the 
Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness, as well as their respective preparatory meetings. 
This will require preparation of case studies and other key documents and reports. The Accra 
Agenda for Action strengthens commitments made in Paris related to several areas including 
transparent and responsible delivery of aid, south–south cooperation, and implementation of 
conditionality practice. As a part of the evolving agenda of the HLE and HLF-4, a number of 
specific issues may be taken up as a part of the HLF-4 round tables and in the preparatory 
activities  for  the  HLE  and  HLF-4.  Some  of  the  examples  of  topics  being  considered  are 
sustainable development, global goods, use of country good practices on mutual accountability, 
and  the  importance  of  regional  perspectives  on  aid  effectiveness  and  development 
effectiveness. The international consultants will assist in developing regional perspectives and 
good  practice  documents  on  HLE  and  HLF-4  issues,  especially  on  conditionality 
implementation, south–south cooperation, or any other work on specific topics of the HLF-4, as 
and when the specific agenda is finalized. 
 
B.  Communications Strategy Expert (international, 1.5 person-months) 
2.  An internationally recruited individual consultant with expertise in communication and 
media will be engaged for 1.5 person-months to work closely with the Strategy, Planning, Policy 
and Interagency Relations Division of ADB’s Strategy and Policy Department to develop a 
coherent communication and dissemination plan to ensure broad stakeholder participation on 
HLF-4 issues. The plan should cover both communication and dissemination plans internally 
within ADB headquarters, in the country offices, and in the developing member countries.   
 
3.  The tasks of the consultant will include developing a communication strategy to publicize 
and disseminate action already being taken, and for broader consultation on major issues of the 
HLE and HLF-4 to create awareness at all levels of country offices of development partners as 
well as in the developing member countries, and for updating ADB’s aid effectiveness website.  
 
C.  Coordinating Expert (national, 12 person-months) 
 
4.  A national consultant (or consultants) will be engaged to help with the effective planning, 
coordination, and conduct of a series of activities regarding the international agenda of aid 
effectiveness, in particular the activities related to preparations for the HLF-4 in the Republic of 
Korea in 2011. He or she will report to staff of the Strategy, Planning, Policy and Interagency 
Relations  Division  and  provide  the  following  administrative  support  to  deliver  the  outputs 
required to achieve the purpose of the assignment: 
 
(i)  Provide and coordinate secretariat support during the workshops to help with 
organization  and  arrangements,  and  assist  in  documenting  the  workshop 
sessions. 
(ii)  Coordinate all necessary logistical arrangements for the subregional workshops, 
including all relevant meetings, consultations, and videoconferences; prepare 
required correspondence and respond to inquiries.

10  Appendix 3 
(iii)  Set up workable arrangements with the resident missions concerned for the 
planning, execution, and monitoring of all activities relevant to the events and 
closely coordinate with them on all logistical and administrative matters. 
(iv)  Help consolidate and synthesize workshop materials and reports, and liaise with 
the printing office for the production of these materials as necessary. 
(v)  Liaise  with  development  partners  who  will  cosponsor  the  workshops  (United 
Nations  Development  Programme,  Government  of  Japan,  World  Bank,  and 
others) with regard to organization, arrangements, and fund transfers; coordinate 
the preparation of necessary letters of agreement for sharing expenses.

  CDDE  –  Capacity Development for Development Effectiveness 
DMC  –  developing member country 
HLE  –  high-level event 
HLF-4  –  Fourth High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness 
MfDR  –  managing for development results 
  OECD-DAC  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-
    Development Assistance Committee  
SPD  –  Strategy and Policy Department 
SSC  –  south-south cooperation 
UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme 
WP-EFF  –  Working Party on Aid Effectiveness 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management, public expenditure and fiscal management, public 
administration) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development; client relations, 
    network, and partnership development); regional cooperation and 
    integration (other regional public goods); governance 
Location Impact  –  Regional (high), national (high)

Nations Development Programme, World Bank, Government of 
Japan
